page.title: 12Recollections
page.content: We interviewed people who have lived in Sandhurst most of their lives to see what their childhoods were like. First we interviewed Mr. Moth who was born in 1910. He lived in Little Sandhurst which was quite separate from Sandhurst. There was no piped water, electricity or telephones. Lighting was from gas lamps. Warmth and cooking came from coal fires. Because he had no pocket money he did a newspaper round for which he earned 7 shillings a week (35p). At Christmas he only received fruits and nuts but never a banana. At school there were few books, instead they wrote on slates. He was naughty and burnt the headmaster's canes. There were no school meals so he brought bread, cheese and onion to eat. In their spare time boys played football or cricket, girls sewed.
